codes.name: AI Applications and Uses
codes.description: This code captures instances where researchers discuss how AI tools are currently being used or could potentially be used to assist with various research tasks, from data analysis to administrative functions. It highlights the practical utility and potential benefits of AI integration.
codes.semantic_definition: Any mention of a specific task or function that AI is performing or is envisioned to perform within the research lifecycle, including data handling, content generation, or process automation.
example_quotes: I have used AI tools to help with my code. I know in general how to execute one of these methods but sometime there are new packages written but my code is having errors so I can take the code and put it in an LLM; can you fix this error or can you write this more concisely?
I mean, couldn't the AI? ... if you could have AI go through the interviews as the first step and help you kind of pick out themes and help you, I think. That would be great.
AI has been really helpful with writing like any type of code I write primarily in Python... it just helped me write code like so much faster.

codes.name: AI Challenges and Risks
codes.description: This code encompasses discussions about the difficulties, limitations, and potential negative consequences associated with the use of AI in research. It includes concerns about data quality, ethical implications, and the inherent boundaries of AI capabilities.
codes.semantic_definition: Any statement identifying a problem, limitation, ethical dilemma, or potential harm arising from the application or misuse of AI tools in research.
example_quotes: The risk is that we will end up utilizing AI for stuff our junior folks used to do... I worry about career development and skillset development among the younger folks.

One of the things researchers are increasingly concerned about is data mining, which is going into a data set and just, you know, looking at all these different options... could it go kinda too far? In ways that make people distrustful of of the results.

The RAND CHAT one is not as good, a couple of times I would ask RAND CHAT, are there systematic studies on blah or what do you know about x and y and it would give me papers/citations that were not real. So I always check.

codes.name: AI Adoption and Integration
codes.description: This code captures discussions related to the factors influencing the uptake, implementation, and effective incorporation of AI tools within a research organization. It covers barriers, drivers, and strategic considerations for organizational AI initiatives.
codes.semantic_definition: Any mention of the current state of AI usage, obstacles to its wider acceptance, motivations for its adoption, or recommendations for organizational strategies to facilitate its integration.
example_quotes: My sense is the Army thinks our competitors are integrating AI wholistically... So how do we make sure we don’t get put out of business in that environment. How do we maintain a competitive edge.

RANDCHAT not as good as just using Chachi PT... I'm not gonna do that if it has sensitive data... So I wanna give all of my code all of the sensitive stuff. And I can do that with ranchat... but it's not gonna help me fix it.
Most ppl I ask, at RAND there are not as many ppl using it; the few that have say they use it to do what I am doing to help fix code or wordsmith text.

codes.name: Impact on Research Process
codes.description: This code focuses on how the integration of AI tools is changing or could change the fundamental ways research is conducted, from efficiency gains and workflow streamlining to the evolution of research design and the need for new training.
codes.semantic_definition: Any discussion about the transformation of research workflows, project timelines, methodological approaches, or the required skills and knowledge for researchers due to AI.
example_quotes: If there were a way to more fully automate that process of the editing, the proofreading everything else were, you know. Dramatically more rapid than they are right now. I I think that right that would feedback I think into literally how I conceptualized the opportunities for research projects.
If you knew you could get this out in time to achieve. A policy impact quickly. It could impact you know how you even conduct a study and meet your own timelines.
There could be more along those lines, showcasing how ppl use it successfully... someone super savvy and using it a lot could give a rundown of how they use it day to day.

codes.name: AI for Qualitative Data Analysis
codes.description: This code covers the use of AI to assist with the analysis of qualitative data, such as identifying themes, coding interviews, and managing textual information. It highlights AI's role in making these often time-consuming tasks more efficient.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's application in processing, interpreting, or organizing non-numerical, descriptive data, particularly from interviews or open-ended responses.
example_quotes: Interview coding, something way better than Dedoose. We do a lot of interviews and the coding is uneven in quality. So it would be great if we had some standard way to do that and a tool to help with that.
I mean, couldn't the AI? ... if you could have AI go through the interviews as the first step and help you kind of pick out themes and help you, I think. That would be great.
It's qualitative coding, but like adding a layer so that AI remembers, remembers and gives you an output which traces back to the original interviews.

codes.name: AI for Quantitative Data Preparation
codes.description: This code focuses on AI's utility in preparing quantitative datasets for analysis, including extracting specific data points from various sources, cleaning data, and generating necessary structural components like variable names.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's role in the initial stages of quantitative research, involving the collection, structuring, and refinement of numerical or structured data before statistical analysis.
example_quotes: We want to characterize different states in terms of the policies they had in place at a given point in time and across all 50 states... have the machine go through and extract the relevant text statements or, you know, other information. Maybe it's data from tables so that we can then create these policy variables.

What if you could? Put the survey into AI and then say create all the variable names for me, right? ... Here's all the names. Here's the data dictionary, essentially, and then here's all the descriptives.

The time-consuming process of pulling data down, checking code... Even if you are collecting the data yourself... We had to go and get it and clean and prepare it for use and check that there are not errors.

codes.name: AI for Research Design and Proposal
codes.description: This code captures the use of AI to assist in the conceptualization, planning, and writing of research proposals and designs. It includes tasks like summarizing existing literature, refining research questions, and structuring proposal content.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's application in the early, conceptual phases of a research project, specifically in developing the research plan, methodology, and the formal documentation (proposals, literature reviews) required for funding or approval.
example_quotes: I’ve also done things for proposal writing and taken my idea where I want to use a particular design and poke holes in this; What are the problems with this; how can I strengthen this?
I take the whole proposal and say write an executive summary; it is great at doing that; you can’t trust it but sometimes stuff that is off and misses nuance but it is pretty good at that.

We did write a python script to use the RAND CHAT to review a bunch of papers... had it spit out in a spreadsheet a once sentence summary of the paper or we asked it questions, is this paper based in the US?

codes.name: AI for Coding and Programming
codes.description: This code focuses on AI's role in assisting researchers with writing, debugging, and optimizing computer code used for data analysis, modeling, or other computational tasks. It highlights AI's ability to accelerate programming efforts.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's direct involvement in the creation, modification, or error-checking of programming scripts or software used in research, particularly in quantitative methods.
example_quotes: I have used AI tools to help with my code. I know in general how to execute one of these methods but sometime there are new packages written but my code is having errors so I can take the code and put it in an LLM; can you fix this error or can you write this more concisely?
I used to get me a good start, you know, kind of figure out how to write it... it just helped me write code like so much faster.
I just can copy all over in and tell it. Please find where my syntax is wrong, but also ask in which tool is the best... Convert something into something else and then I is usually really helpful.

codes.name: AI for Administrative and Communication Tasks
codes.description: This code captures the use of AI for general administrative support and enhancing communication clarity within research projects. It includes tasks like meeting management, text summarization, and simplifying complex information.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's application in non-core research activities that support project management, team coordination, or the effective dissemination of research findings to diverse audiences.
example_quotes: Meeting minutes like just having AI transcribed the meeting minutes put it in like here are the key decisions. Here are the action items.
My husband was using Claude and told me it is good at writing things... I would take “Reddit explain like I’m 5”. Esp with methods, hard for ppl who are not experts to understand.
I’ve played a little with telling it to, to make an image for proposal. Somewhere you can say, I want something that looks like an experiment but relevant to labor markets.

codes.name: AI for Data Collection
codes.description: This code refers to the potential future use of AI to automate aspects of data collection, such as conducting interviewer-assisted surveys or interviews, by engaging with respondents and following complex protocols.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's envisioned role in directly interacting with human subjects or systems to gather primary data through structured or semi-structured methods.
example_quotes: I'm wondering, you know, do we can we get to a point someday where that kind of data collection is done by machine rather than humans? ... the machine goes out and does the interviews.

I mean, I can imagine and maybe this is happening now, but you know you'd want to avoid sounding like a machine. Want it to sound like it's a human and somebody who's able to respond when somebody says I don't know.

codes.name: Data Quality and Reliability Concerns
codes.description: This code addresses concerns about the accuracy, trustworthiness, and potential for misleading results when using AI tools. It includes issues like AI generating false information and the risks of statistical overfitting.
codes.semantic_definition: Any statement expressing doubt or caution regarding the factual correctness, statistical validity, or potential for misinterpretation of outputs generated or influenced by AI.
example_quotes: One of the things researchers are increasingly concerned about is data mining, which is going into a data set and just, you know, looking at all these different options... could it go kinda too far? In ways that make people distrustful of of the results.

I'm not sure if people use AI in that sense, but I would hope that kind of any quant researcher right is familiar with the concept of overfitting... there needs to be more education about this idea of of overfitting.

The RAND CHAT one is not as good, a couple of times I would ask RAND CHAT, are there systematic studies on blah or what do you know about x and y and it would give me papers/citations that were not real. So I always check.

codes.name: Ethical and Intellectual Property Concerns
codes.description: This code covers ethical dilemmas and intellectual property issues arising from AI use, such as the potential for plagiarism, copyright infringement, or the detection of sensitive content.
codes.semantic_definition: Any discussion about the moral implications, ownership rights, or potential for misuse of AI-generated content or AI's interaction with sensitive information.
example_quotes: The other thing I’ve done; I’ve taken text and said which of the sentences in here will upset some opposed to DEI and it will flag sentences and makes me look at it again.

I don’t want to inadvertently take someone else’s intellectual property. Saw a thing on john Oliver, ppl making images, based on what is in the public and making something new so it is kind of stealing. I don’t want to take anyone’s intellectual property.

Working with our hspc, the IRB Institutional Review Board... being kind of ahead of the curve in how these tools might be used and what the implications are. For consent or the kind of information that you collect and and retain.

codes.name: AI Impact on Workforce
codes.description: This code addresses concerns about how AI might affect the roles, career development, and skill acquisition of researchers, particularly junior staff, if AI automates tasks traditionally performed by them.
codes.semantic_definition: Any discussion about the displacement of human labor, changes in required skills, or the impact on professional growth within a research organization due to AI adoption.
example_quotes: The risk is that we will end up utilizing AI for stuff our junior folks used to do. We can use AI for a literature review that would have taken a RA 20 days so benefits of cost savings but I worry about career development and skillset development among the younger folks.

codes.name: Inherent Limitations of AI
codes.description: This code captures discussions about the tasks or cognitive processes that AI tools are currently not well-suited for, such as complex research design, nuanced human interaction, or critical scientific reasoning.
codes.semantic_definition: Any statement defining a boundary or inherent inability of AI to perform certain intellectual or interpersonal functions that are crucial to the research process.
example_quotes: I think that developing the questions needs more thought. I'm not sure AI could do that... To me, that's a thinking process.

It is not going to necessarily help you figure out what you need to do. The researcher has honed that overtime so not easily replicating it... As opposed to thinking through the logic of the science and thinking is it credible, that is harder (for ai).

I mean, I can imagine and maybe this is happening now, but you know you'd want to avoid sounding like a machine. Want it to sound like it's a human and somebody who's able to respond when somebody says I don't know.

codes.name: Barriers to AI Adoption
codes.description: This code identifies specific obstacles hindering the widespread and effective adoption of AI tools within a research organization, including issues with tool quality, security policies, and lack of awareness.
codes.semantic_definition: Any factor or condition explicitly stated as impeding or slowing down the integration or use of AI technologies by researchers.
example_quotes: RANDCHAT not as good as just using Chachi PT... I'm not gonna do that if it has sensitive data... So I wanna give all of my code all of the sensitive stuff. And I can do that with ranchat... but it's not gonna help me fix it.
The unavailability of those things on classified networks. So if you work on classified stuff for this whole part of your thing, this whole world doesn't really exist right now.

I don’t know if ppl feel like they are not supposed to use these bc I know RAND has its own specific rand chat and rand came out and said don’t use something, so part of me wonders if ppl are hesitant for that reason.

codes.name: Drivers for AI Adoption
codes.description: This code captures the motivations and pressures that encourage researchers and organizations to adopt AI tools, such as the desire to remain competitive, achieve efficiency gains, or meet client demands.
codes.semantic_definition: Any factor or incentive explicitly stated as promoting or accelerating the integration or use of AI technologies by researchers.
example_quotes: My sense is the Army thinks our competitors are integrating AI wholistically... So how do we make sure we don’t get put out of business in that environment. How do we maintain a competitive edge.
The main reason we did that was because the client a federal agency wanted us to do this massive literature review in one month.
I personally feel others are using this and I should… it is speeding things up for ppl in a way that makes me feel I don’t want to be left behind but I feel a little about it.

codes.name: Organizational AI Strategy
codes.description: This code refers to discussions about the need for a coherent, institution-wide approach to AI adoption, including coordinated initiatives and preparedness of internal review boards for AI-related ethical considerations.
codes.semantic_definition: Any recommendation or observation regarding the institutional policies, frameworks, or readiness required to manage and guide the responsible integration of AI within a research organization.
example_quotes: Need to be company wide ai initiatives that every unit and division are asked to participate in.

Working with our hspc, the IRB Institutional Review Board... being kind of ahead of the curve in how these tools might be used and what the implications are. For consent or the kind of information that you collect and and retain.

codes.name: Research Efficiency Gains
codes.description: This code highlights how AI contributes to making research processes faster, less labor-intensive, and more streamlined, ultimately leading to quicker project completion and dissemination of findings.
codes.semantic_definition: Any statement describing how AI reduces the time, effort, or resources required for various research tasks, or accelerates the overall research and publication cycle.
example_quotes: If there were a way to more fully automate that process of the editing, the proofreading everything else were, you know. Dramatically more rapid than they are right now. I I think that right that would feedback I think into literally how I conceptualized the opportunities for research projects.
If you knew you could get this out in time to achieve. A policy impact quickly. It could impact you know how you even conduct a study and meet your own timelines.
Summaries I found AI super helpful and that's probably was one of the. 1st. Objectives of first use cases to summarize stuff, and it's been super helpful saving a lot of time.

codes.name: Evolution of Research Design
codes.description: This code captures discussions about how the capabilities of AI might fundamentally alter the types of research questions asked, the methodologies employed, or the overall strategic planning of research projects.
codes.semantic_definition: Any observation or prediction about how AI's influence could lead to changes in the conceptualization, scope, or strategic direction of research studies.
example_quotes: I think that right that would feedback I think into literally how I conceptualized the opportunities for research projects... reshape the types of things that I would try to do.
If we could forecast more accurately in the outset then we could have more accurate recommendations than competitors.

codes.name: AI Training and Education Needs
codes.description: This code identifies the need for educational resources and training programs to help researchers understand how to effectively and responsibly use AI tools, including best practices and how to mitigate risks.
codes.semantic_definition: Any explicit mention of the requirement for learning materials, workshops, or guidance to improve researchers' proficiency, awareness, or ethical conduct in using AI.
example_quotes: I'm not sure if people use AI in that sense, but I would hope that kind of any quant researcher right is familiar with the concept of overfitting... there needs to be more education about this idea of of overfitting.

It would be for folks to have sort of illustrated use case guides for, OK. Let's say you wanna use large language models to do X. Here's some literal examples of how this is used and how this fit into an actual project lifecycle.

There could be more along those lines, showcasing how ppl use it successfully. A little bit but not a ton and someone super savvy and using it a lot could give a rundown of how they use it day to day.

codes.name: AI for Coding and Thematic Analysis
codes.description: This code refers to the application of AI tools to automatically identify, categorize, and extract themes from qualitative data, such as interview transcripts. It aims to standardize and improve the efficiency of the coding process.
codes.semantic_definition: The use of AI to perform or assist in the systematic labeling, grouping, and interpretation of textual data to uncover patterns and themes.
example_quotes: Interview coding, something way better than Dedoose. We do a lot of interviews and the coding is uneven in quality. So it would be great if we had some standard way to do that and a tool to help with that.
I mean, couldn't the AI? ... if you could have AI go through the interviews as the first step and help you kind of pick out themes and help you, I think. That would be great.

codes.name: AI for Qualitative Data Management
codes.description: This code captures the use of AI to organize, track, and retrieve specific pieces of qualitative data, such as quotes, and to generate citations, thereby streamlining the management of large qualitative datasets.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's function in structuring, indexing, and facilitating the retrieval and referencing of qualitative data elements.
example_quotes: I found AI very helpful in tracking in tracing it back to the interview. So when you have a very good quote... It's kind of helpful in organizing the notes in a way that it's very, very easy. To trace back to the interview to the specific moment of a point in your data set that you can easily recite and create these citations for you.

codes.name: AI for Data Extraction
codes.description: This code refers to AI's capability to automatically pull specific information, including text statements or data from tables, out of various document formats (e.g., PDFs, scanned documents) for use in quantitative models.
codes.semantic_definition: The automated retrieval of structured or semi-structured data points from unstructured or diverse sources using AI.
example_quotes: We want to characterize different states in terms of the policies they had in place... have the machine go through and extract the relevant text statements or, you know, other information. Maybe it's data from tables so that we can then create these policy variables.

AI Useful for pulling data? Even if you are collecting the data yourself... Could be taking publicly available datasets, a lot of the federal, some federal agencies are using the Api where you can tell it each time you run your code, go to this external website and pull data down fresh.

codes.name: AI for Data Cleaning and Preparation
codes.description: This code covers the use of AI to assist in the process of cleaning, preparing, and checking quantitative datasets for errors, ensuring data quality before analysis.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's role in identifying and correcting inconsistencies, errors, or missing values in datasets to make them suitable for analysis.
example_quotes: I think they all have to deal with missing data and how are you gonna address missing or lost a follow up data. Those are things that I think could be automated in some way.

The time-consuming process of pulling data down, checking code... Even if you are collecting the data yourself... We had to go and get it and clean and prepare it for use and check that there are not errors.

codes.name: AI for Variable and Data Dictionary Creation
codes.description: This code refers to AI's ability to automatically generate variable names and data dictionaries from survey instruments, streamlining the initial setup of quantitative datasets.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's function in translating survey questions or raw data into structured variables and their corresponding metadata.
example_quotes: What if you could? Put the survey into AI and then say create all the variable names for me, right? ... Here's all the names. Here's the data dictionary, essentially, and then here's all the descriptives.

codes.name: AI for Proposal Writing Assistance
codes.description: This code captures the use of AI to aid in drafting and refining research proposals, including generating executive summaries, identifying weaknesses in proposed designs, and suggesting improvements.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's role in generating, critiquing, or enhancing the textual content and structural elements of research proposals.
example_quotes: I’ve also done things for proposal writing and taken my idea where I want to use a particular design and poke holes in this; What are the problems with this; how can I strengthen this?
I take the whole proposal and say write an executive summary; it is great at doing that; you can’t trust it but sometimes stuff that is off and misses nuance but it is pretty good at that.

codes.name: AI for Literature Review and Synthesis
codes.description: This code refers to AI's application in conducting and summarizing literature reviews, including sifting through large volumes of papers, extracting key information, and translating foreign language texts.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's function in systematically identifying, processing, summarizing, and translating existing academic or professional literature relevant to a research topic.
example_quotes: We can use AI for a literature review that would have taken a RA 20 days so benefits of cost savings.
I work with a lot of foreign language literature and AI helps a lot. It's much better than Google Translate... Summaries I found AI super helpful.

We did write a python script to use the RAND CHAT to review a bunch of papers... had it spit out in a spreadsheet a once sentence summary of the paper or we asked it questions, is this paper based in the US?

codes.name: AI for Code Generation
codes.description: This code captures the use of AI to write new programming code from scratch or to convert existing code between different programming languages, significantly accelerating the development process.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's ability to produce functional programming scripts or translate them from one language to another based on user prompts or existing code.
example_quotes: AI has been really helpful with writing like any type of code I write primarily in Python... it just helped me write code like so much faster.
I found someone else’s code and asked can you convert this R code to Stata code and kept playing with it and learned what is good and not good.

codes.name: AI for Code Debugging and Optimization
codes.description: This code refers to AI's utility in identifying and fixing errors in programming code, as well as suggesting ways to make code more concise or efficient.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's function in analyzing programming scripts to detect and resolve errors, or to suggest improvements for performance or readability.
example_quotes: I have used AI tools to help with my code... my code is having errors so I can take the code and put it in an LLM; can you fix this error or can you write this more concisely?
I just can copy all over in and tell it. Please find where my syntax is wrong.
The time-consuming process of pulling data down, checking code... then you can use the ai tools to check the code, annotate the code, replicability those are time consuming and for AI.

codes.name: AI for Meeting Management
codes.description: This code covers the use of AI to automate tasks related to managing meetings, such as transcribing discussions, identifying key decisions, and extracting action items.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's application in streamlining the administrative aspects of meetings, from recording content to summarizing outcomes and assigning responsibilities.
example_quotes: Meeting minutes like just having AI transcribed the meeting minutes put it in like here are the key decisions. Here are the action items.
Otter? That tool is used for research. Providers and patients and they are using Otter to take notes and it transcribes and summarizes.

codes.name: AI for Communication Clarity
codes.description: This code refers to AI's utility in enhancing the clarity and conciseness of written communication, including rewriting text, shortening content, and simplifying complex concepts for broader audiences.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's function in refining written output to improve its readability, brevity, or accessibility to different stakeholders.
example_quotes: My husband was using Claude and told me it is good at writing things... sometimes to re-write or shorten things... I would take “Reddit explain like I’m 5”. Esp with methods, hard for ppl who are not experts to understand.
Summaries I found AI super helpful... it does a very good job.

codes.name: AI for Data Visualization
codes.description: This code captures the use of AI tools to generate images, graphics, or other visual representations of data for reports and proposals, aiming to improve presentation quality.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's role in creating visual aids or graphical content to illustrate research findings or concepts.
example_quotes: Something that helps us with graphics. It would be great if we were not one person deep on Evonne Crane. Great to make graphics that were accurate. I am trying to make one in chatgpt and it makes people without arms and I can’t edit it.
I’ve played a little with telling it to, to make an image for proposal. Somewhere you can say, I want something that looks like an experiment but relevant to labor markets.

codes.name: AI for Automated Data Collection (Interviews)
codes.description: This code refers to the potential future use of AI to conduct interviewer-assisted surveys or interviews, automating the process of engaging with respondents and following complex protocols.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's envisioned role in directly interacting with human subjects to gather primary data through structured or semi-structured questioning.
example_quotes: I'm wondering, you know, do we can we get to a point someday where that kind of data collection is done by machine rather than humans? ... the machine goes out and does the interviews.

I mean, I can imagine and maybe this is happening now, but you know you'd want to avoid sounding like a machine. Want it to sound like it's a human and somebody who's able to respond when somebody says I don't know.

codes.name: AI Hallucinations and Inaccuracy
codes.description: This code addresses the phenomenon where AI generates false information, fake citations, or inaccurate content, highlighting the need for human verification and critical assessment of AI outputs.
codes.semantic_definition: Instances where AI produces fabricated, incorrect, or non-existent data, facts, or references.
example_quotes: Especially hallucinations. I know a lot of researchers are pretty freaked out about. You know, given the sort of reputational risks involved in that kind of thing.
The RAND CHAT one is not as good, a couple of times I would ask RAND CHAT... and it would give me papers/citations that were not real. So I always check.

codes.name: AI Overfitting and Data Mining Risks
codes.description: This code captures concerns about AI's potential to facilitate data mining or overfitting in statistical models, leading to spurious correlations or results that are not robust or generalizable.
codes.semantic_definition: The risk that AI's computational power could be used to excessively search for patterns in data, leading to models that perform well on training data but poorly on new data, or to findings that are not statistically sound.
example_quotes: One of the things researchers are increasingly concerned about is data mining, which is going into a data set and just, you know, looking at all these different options... could it go kinda too far? In ways that make people distrustful of of the results.
I'm not sure if people use AI in that sense, but I would hope that kind of any quant researcher right is familiar with the concept of overfitting.

codes.name: AI and Intellectual Property
codes.description: This code addresses concerns about the ownership and potential infringement of intellectual property when using AI tools, particularly regarding AI-generated content that might draw from existing copyrighted works.
codes.semantic_definition: Discussions about the legal and ethical implications of AI's use of existing data or content, and the originality or ownership of AI-produced outputs.
example_quotes: I don’t want to inadvertently take someone else’s intellectual property. Saw a thing on john Oliver, ppl making images, based on what is in the public and making something new so it is kind of stealing. I don’t want to take anyone’s intellectual property.
But if I were to take my proposal and say write this, is it going to take texts from others?

codes.name: AI for Bias Detection
codes.description: This code refers to the use of AI to identify potentially biased or sensitive language in research outputs, such as flagging sentences that might be controversial or offensive to certain groups.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's function in reviewing text for language that could be perceived as prejudiced, discriminatory, or politically charged.
example_quotes: The other thing I’ve done; I’ve taken text and said which of the sentences in here will upset some opposed to DEI and it will flag sentences and makes me look at it again.
Ppl are surprised? Like asking LLM about getting DEI flagged? I don’t think ppl are doing that at rand and I’m not sure why bc we have the rand chat.

codes.name: AI and IRB/Ethical Review Implications
codes.description: This code addresses the need for Institutional Review Boards (IRBs) or Human Subjects Protection Committees (HSPCs) to adapt to and understand the ethical implications of AI tools, particularly concerning informed consent and data handling.
codes.semantic_definition: Discussions about the challenges and requirements for ethical oversight bodies to develop guidelines and expertise for AI-assisted research, especially regarding human subjects.
example_quotes: Working with our hspc, the IRB Institutional Review Board, since I'm assuming most all these projects, especially if they involve real people, we'll have to have some type of clearance. And again, being kind of ahead of the curve in how these tools might be used and what the implications are. For consent or the kind of information that you collect and and retain.

codes.name: AI Impact on Junior Staff Development
codes.description: This code highlights concerns that AI's automation of entry-level research tasks (e.g., literature reviews) could hinder the career development and skill acquisition of junior researchers.
codes.semantic_definition: The potential negative effect of AI on the learning opportunities, skill-building, and career progression of less experienced research personnel.
example_quotes: The risk is that we will end up utilizing AI for stuff our junior folks used to do. We can use AI for a literature review that would have taken a RA 20 days so benefits of cost savings but I worry about career development and skillset development among the younger folks.

codes.name: AI Limitations in Research Design
codes.description: This code refers to the perceived inability of AI to effectively contribute to the complex, creative, and critical thinking aspects of research design, such as formulating research questions or developing scientific logic.
codes.semantic_definition: The inherent boundaries of AI's capacity to engage in high-level conceptualization, problem-framing, or methodological innovation in research.
example_quotes: I think that developing the questions needs more thought. I'm not sure AI could do that... To me, that's a thinking process.

It is not going to necessarily help you figure out what you need to do. The researcher has honed that overtime so not easily replicating it... As opposed to thinking through the logic of the science and thinking is it credible, that is harder (for ai).

codes.name: AI Limitations in Contextual Understanding
codes.description: This code addresses AI's current shortcomings in handling nuanced human interactions, clarifying complex concepts, or responding adaptively in real-time data collection scenarios like interviews.
codes.semantic_definition: The inability of AI to fully grasp subtle social cues, provide dynamic clarifications, or engage in flexible, human-like dialogue during data collection or interpretation.
example_quotes: I mean, I can imagine and maybe this is happening now, but you know you'd want to avoid sounding like a machine. Want it to sound like it's a human and somebody who's able to respond when somebody says I don't know. And now I need to follow some other pathway to try to elicit the response or need to clarify a particular concept or term.

codes.name: AI Tool Quality Issues
codes.description: This code refers to instances where the performance or capabilities of available AI tools (especially internal ones) are perceived as inferior to external alternatives, hindering their adoption.
codes.semantic_definition: Any statement indicating that the functionality, accuracy, or user experience of an AI tool is inadequate or less effective compared to other options.
example_quotes: RANDCHAT not as good as just using Chachi PT... it's not gonna help me fix it. So then I like, OK, I'm gonna go to the better product which is chat CPT.
The RAND CHAT one is not as good, a couple of times I would ask RAND CHAT... and it would give me papers/citations that were not real.

codes.name: AI Security and Policy Restrictions
codes.description: This code captures how security concerns, internal policies, or the unavailability of AI tools on classified networks act as barriers to their broader adoption within a research organization.
codes.semantic_definition: Any organizational rule, technical limitation, or security-related concern that restricts or discourages the use of AI tools.
example_quotes: The unavailability of those things on classified networks. So if you work on classified stuff for this whole part of your thing, this whole world doesn't really exist right now.

I don’t know if ppl feel like they are not supposed to use these bc I know RAND has its own specific rand chat and rand came out and said don’t use something, so part of me wonders if ppl are hesitant for that reason.

codes.name: Lack of AI Awareness
codes.description: This code refers to the observation that many researchers are unaware of the potential applications or successful use cases of AI tools, contributing to low adoption rates.
codes.semantic_definition: A state where researchers are not informed about the capabilities, benefits, or practical examples of AI integration in research.
example_quotes: Most ppl I ask, at RAND there are not as many ppl using it.
Ppl are surprised? Like asking LLM about getting DEI flagged? I don’t think ppl are doing that at rand and I’m not sure why bc we have the rand chat.

codes.name: Competitive Pressure for AI Adoption
codes.description: This code highlights the motivation to adopt AI driven by the perception that competitors or other organizations are integrating AI more comprehensively, creating a fear of being left behind.
codes.semantic_definition: External or internal pressure to adopt AI due to the perceived advanced AI integration by rival entities or the broader research community.
example_quotes: My sense is the Army thinks our competitors are integrating AI wholistically... So how do we make sure we don’t get put out of business in that environment. How do we maintain a competitive edge.
I personally feel others are using this and I should… it is speeding things up for ppl in a way that makes me feel I don’t want to be left behind but I feel a little about it.

codes.name: Efficiency Gains as Adoption Driver
codes.description: This code captures the motivation to adopt AI due to its potential to significantly speed up research tasks, save time, and reduce labor costs.
codes.semantic_definition: The primary benefit of increased speed, reduced effort, or cost savings achieved through AI automation, serving as a reason for its adoption.
example_quotes: We can use AI for a literature review that would have taken a RA 20 days so benefits of cost savings.
Summaries I found AI super helpful and that's probably was one of the. 1st. Objectives of first use cases to summarize stuff, and it's been super helpful saving a lot of time.
I personally feel others are using this and I should… it is speeding things up for ppl in a way that makes me feel I don’t want to be left behind.

codes.name: Company-Wide AI Initiatives
codes.description: This code refers to the call for or implementation of coordinated, institution-wide strategies and initiatives to guide and promote the responsible adoption of AI across all departments.
codes.semantic_definition: A unified, top-down approach or recommendation for an organization to develop and implement a comprehensive strategy for AI integration.
example_quotes: Need to be company wide ai initiatives that every unit and division are asked to participate in.

codes.name: AI for Streamlined Workflows
codes.description: This code describes how AI automates and optimizes various steps in the research process, leading to more efficient and less labor-intensive workflows.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's role in simplifying, automating, or improving the sequence of tasks and operations within a research project.
example_quotes: If somebody could help me like take a project and say here are. All the things that need to happen in terms of IRB review... and help identify the critical paths so that you're always working. The most efficiently.
I think that the data I think almost every project has to do descriptive right, provide sort of what is the description of the data... Those are things that I think could be automated in some way.
The post process. If there were a way to more fully automate that process of the editing, the proofreading everything else were, you know. Dramatically more rapid than they are right now.

codes.name: AI for Rapid Research Dissemination
codes.description: This code highlights how AI can accelerate the final stages of research, such as editing and proofreading, enabling quicker publication and more timely policy impact.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's contribution to reducing the time required for post-production tasks, thereby speeding up the release of research findings and their influence on policy.
example_quotes: If there were a way to more fully automate that process of the editing, the proofreading everything else were, you know. Dramatically more rapid than they are right now... that would feedback I think into literally how I conceptualized the opportunities for research projects.
If you knew you could get this out in time to achieve. A policy impact quickly. It could impact you know how you even conduct a study and meet your own timelines.

codes.name: AI Redefining Research Scope
codes.description: This code captures the idea that AI's capabilities, particularly its speed and efficiency, could fundamentally change the types of research questions that are considered feasible or the strategic focus of research projects.
codes.semantic_definition: The transformative effect of AI on the boundaries, ambition, or strategic direction of research inquiries and project planning.
example_quotes: I think that right that would feedback I think into literally how I conceptualized the opportunities for research projects... reshape the types of things that I would try to do.
If we could forecast more accurately in the outset then we could have more accurate recommendations than competitors.

codes.name: AI Use Case Guides
codes.description: This code highlights the need for practical, illustrated guides that demonstrate specific, successful applications of AI tools within the research lifecycle, helping researchers understand how to integrate them.
codes.semantic_definition: Educational resources providing concrete, step-by-step examples of how AI has been effectively used in actual research projects.
example_quotes: It would be for folks to have sort of illustrated use case guides for, OK. Let's say you wanna use large language models to do X. Here's some literal examples of how this is used and how this fit into an actual project lifecycle.

I was going to say exactly the same thing. I started using it for literature reviews. After I went to a seminar that somebody did on using ranchat for literature reviews and was like OK. So having use case scenarios specific use case scenarios would be very helpful and I would start simple.

codes.name: AI Best Practices and Pitfall Training
codes.description: This code refers to the need for training on best practices for using AI, including how to deal with common pitfalls like hallucinations, overfitting, and ensuring responsible adoption.
codes.semantic_definition: Educational content focused on optimal methods for AI utilization and strategies for mitigating risks and ethical challenges.
example_quotes: How they dealt with pitfalls that came across. Especially hallucinations... And sort of what best practices are, but in a much more concrete, you know, illustrated manner to to walk through, feel through that.

I'm not sure if people use AI in that sense, but I would hope that kind of any quant researcher right is familiar with the concept of overfitting... there needs to be more education about this idea of of overfitting.

discovery_method: You are an expert qualitative researcher, analyzing 3 interviews to discover thematic codes.
analytic_question: How are researchers experiencing and adapting to the integration of AI tools in qualitative research methods?
